user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelay_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelay_Impl(uint32 millisecond)
{
    struct timespec sleep_end;
    int             status;

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &sleep_end);
    sleep_end.tv_sec += millisecond / 1000;
    sleep_end.tv_nsec += 1000000 * (millisecond % 1000);

    if (sleep_end.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
    {
        sleep_end.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
        ++sleep_end.tv_sec;
    }

    do
    {
        status = clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, TIMER_ABSTIME, &sleep_end, NULL);
    } while (status == EINTR);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return OS_SUCCESS;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskDelay_Impl:
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 prohibits using the standard library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. I inspected the provided function and its related symbol definitions and found no use of memcmp or any other standard string-comparison functions. The function only manipulates a struct timespec, integer arithmetic, and calls clock_gettime/clock_nanosleep; there are no char* or string objects, no string headers referenced, and no comparisons of null-terminated strings. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need to be investigated for Rule 21.14.
